Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Measuring the Value of Anonymous Online Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many ordinary people desire anonymous communication for good reason, such as to keep their medical histories confidential or their finances to themselves. People in totalitarian countries may want to communicate about their views anonymously. This project could enable anonymous participation in spaces like Wikipedia and Reddit, while avoiding the negative social behaviors for these online communities of such participation. This research examines the trade-offs in using users' identifiability to reduce bad behavior on online sites versus allowing anonymity, which could allow some users to participate and possibly contribute valuable content without fear of reprisal. The empirical research will clarify the effects of online identifiability and anonymity in influencing the production of counter-normative versus useful behavior, and explore ways to introduce accountability into anonymous speech. The research could have potential use for policy, and online communities and libraries. The project also includes research experiences for teachers.

The research uses experiments to understand the effects of anonymity on contributions and others' judgments, and qualitative research to understand service providers' and users' beliefs about the threats associated with identified and anonymous participation. The proposed software development has the purpose of reducing inappropriate behavior by uncovering only identifying information that predicts bad behavior. In addition, the empirical results will help answer fundamental questions in social psychology about when anonymity is valuable and when it encourages inappropriate behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, team members from New York University, the University of Washington, and Drexel University collaborated to make scientific advances to enable a more innovative and vibrant Internet. We used methods from machine learning, computational social science, and human-computer interaction in cooperation with organizations like the Wikimedia Foundation and the Tor Project to better understand the value of anonymous online participation. Our research provides scientific evidence showing how social and technological infrastructures can both facilitate and impede productive, anonymous participation in a range of online spaces.

The results of this award include empirical, theoretical, and design contributions. For example, using wiki platforms as field sites, we designed a series of empirical studies to identify the kinds of contributions anonymous participants make to online projects. We found that people were more likely to seek anonymity when making contributions to topics that carried social risk and that, in some cases, anonymity protections are vital for protecting people’s safe participation. We explored the impact of policies on anonymous contributions and discovered differences between Internet users’ goals in seeking anonymity and the goals of the service providers that may provide anonymity protections. We also uncovered and documented threat models held by groups like activists, information professionals, and marginalized groups. 

This award has resulted in thirteen peer-reviewed papers in premier research venues, three databases now available to the research community for further analysis, two completed doctoral dissertations, a third approved dissertation proposal, and a completed master’s thesis. This work advanced the state-of-the-art in privacy-related theories and frameworks. It engaged directly with organizations providing online participation platforms and services to build a scientific understanding of on-the-ground challenges and to describe and evaluate potential pathways toward the support of anonymous participation online. In particular, we thoroughly assessed alternative moderation models that allow for more anonymous participation, like pre-publication review. Synthesizing this work, we published recommendations for online platforms that want to explore solutions for enabling anonymous participation.
